metadata.h1: Solving non-linear problems with genetic algorithms (Part 2)
metadata.description: In this series of articles, discover how genetic algorithms (also called evolutionary algorithms) can help you solve non-linear problems!

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: the model described in the first article

all_paragraphs: In the first part of this series (here), I introduced the issue of optimizing non-linear problems that are not differentiable and for which standard optimizing libraries are useless.
If you are familiar with genetic algorithms, you know that they mimic the natural selection process by keeping the individuals who are the most adapted to their environment.

In the examples I will be using in these articles, this can be translated as follows: the individual characteristics (the combination of values set for each feature) interact with the environment (the non-linear model) which determines the individual’s destiny (the closer from the target the regression result is, the higher the chances of survival are!)
We first explored a very simple methodology, which consisted of applying the largest possible number of solutions (= individuals) to the non-linear model and picking the best ones.
However, this method might require a lot of computation power and time as the number of features and complexity level of the model increase.
Before we jump into permutations and mutations (which are the traditional methods used), I would like to offer an alternative technique I am using with good results.
However, please keep in mind that I am using this optimization technique for industry modeling problems and it could (probably) fail in other areas.
I will be slightly changing the original approach of maximizing the number of potentials solutions by progressively reducing the universe explored.
Let’s explain the underlying idea with one single feature: X1:
The initial universe of this feature corresponds to the min-max range of observations. So, if X1 is varying between 30 and 50, we should create individuals with the same characteristics.
However, it is quite likely that the optimum value(s) of X1 belongs to a smaller range.

For example, consider that X1 corresponds to a temperature and that it contributes best to the target between 35° and 42°. The exact and optimum temperature will be ultimately defined by other production parameters and/or constraints (flow rate, viscosity, etc.).
